image_analysis.description: A black and white scan of a two-page spread from a book or bound document. The text discusses Jeffrey Epstein and an individual named Rodriguez who allegedly stole information from Epstein and attempted to sell it. The document has a Bates stamp in the bottom right corner, indicating it is part of a larger collection of documents, likely for legal or investigative purposes.
image_analysis.layout: Two-column layout representing two pages of a book. Page 218 is on the left, and page 21 is on the right. Each page has a header and a footer with page numbers. The binding of the book is visible in the center.

text_extraction.full_text:
JAMES PATTERSON

Jeffrey Epstein. Finally, desperately, he tried to sell the informa-tion he’d stolen.

The papers named underage girls and the places where Epstein had taken them. The list included locations in Califor-nia, Paris, New Mexico, New York, and Michigan. The papers also included the names, addresses, and phone numbers of famous individuals—Henry Kissinger, Mick Jagger, Dustin Hoff-man, Ralph Fiennes, David Koch, Ted Kennedy, Donald Trump, Bill Richardson, Bill Clinton, and former Israeli prime minister Ehud Barak among them.

This was intriguing, if not at all damning. Epstein made a habit of collecting such information for future use. But informa-tion pertaining to the girls would have bolstered the state’s case against Jeffrey Epstein, and by withholding it from the Palm Beach PD and the FBI, Rodriguez had committed a crime.

In his defense, Rodriguez would say that the papers were an “insurance policy.” Without them, he believed, Epstein would have made him “disappear.”

But now Rodriguez needed the money. And so a few weeks after Epstein’s release from the Stockade, he approached a lawyer who was representing some of Epstein’s masseuses. He had the “holy grail,” he insisted. A “golden nugget.” The names of hun-dreds of girls, he said, who had been abused by Epstein.

The lawyer told Rodriguez in no uncertain terms that he was obliged to turn whatever he had over to the authorities. By demanding money for the information, Rodriguez was commit-ting another crime.

According to a sworn statement by Christina Pryor, a special agent with the FBI, Rodriguez “persisted that he would only turn over the information in his possession in exchange for $50,000.”

document_metadata.subject: Attempt by an individual named Rodriguez to sell information stolen from Jeffrey Epstein.

notes: The document appears to be an excerpt from a book by James Patterson, which has been entered as evidence or documentation for a House Oversight Committee investigation, as indicated by the Bates stamp. The text on the right page is cut off along the right margin, making some words incomplete. The page numbering (218 on the left, 21 on the right) is unusual and may indicate the pages are from different sections or documents compiled together.
